title: Settings page broken after login
description: After a successful OAuth login, the settings page in the client app is broken. Root cause unknown — needs investigation. Discovered during end-to-end testing of the maearth-demo app.

title: Prevent flash of email login form when login_hint is present
description:
When /oauth/authorize is called with a login_hint email, the current implementation renders the full login page (including the email input step) and then client-side JS transitions to the OTP step after sending the OTP. This causes a brief flash of the email input form before the OTP step appears, which is confusing to users who already entered their email in the client app.

Fix: when login_hint is a valid email, send the OTP server-side during the GET /oauth/authorize handler and render the page already in the OTP step (hiding the email step entirely via HTML/CSS). No client-side transition needed — the OTP step should be immediately visible with no flash.

title: Restructure docs: README for frontend devs, internals in docs/
description:
The README.md currently mixes two audiences:
1. Frontend developers building client apps against the ePDS
2. Contributors working on the ePDS itself

Split these concerns:
- README.md should focus purely on helping frontend developers understand how to build against the ePDS: the two login flows, PAR/OAuth endpoints, login_hint convention, client metadata, callback handling, etc.
- Internal architecture, package structure, deployment, configuration, and development setup should move to docs/ subdirectory (e.g. docs/architecture.md, docs/deployment.md, docs/development.md)

The Mermaid sequence diagrams (atproto-y1l) should go in docs/ as part of this restructure.

title: Eliminate auth server redirect in flow 1 (app has own email form)
description:
In flow 1, where the client app collects the user's email itself and passes it as login_hint, there is no reason to redirect through /oauth/authorize at all before showing the OTP input. The current flow is:

1. App collects email
2. App POSTs to /api/oauth/login → PAR → redirects to /oauth/authorize?login_hint=email
3. Auth server renders login page, JS auto-sends OTP, transitions to OTP step
4. User enters OTP

Step 3 is unnecessary indirection. Ideally the app could redirect directly to an OTP input page on the auth server, skipping the intermediate login page entirely. This would require a dedicated endpoint (e.g. /oauth/authorize/otp-challenge) that accepts login_hint, sends OTP server-side, and renders the OTP input directly — no login form involved at all.

title: Investigate server-side OTP send on login_hint (magic-pds vs current approach)
description:
The old magic-pds branch handled login_hint by sending the OTP server-side in the GET /oauth/authorize handler and rendering the OTP form directly as a full-page response (no flash, no JS transition needed). See authorize.ts on the magic-pds branch.

The current main branch unified everything into a single page (login-page.ts) with CSS show/hide and a JS-driven OTP send on page load. The uncommitted changes in login-page.ts are a partial improvement (pre-render OTP step server-side) but still send the OTP client-side via JS, so the subtitle 'We sent a code to...' is inaccurate at render time.

The proper fix is likely to restore the server-side OTP send approach from magic-pds, but the unified single-page architecture is different enough that this needs careful thought.

Investigation needed (requires owner input):
1. Produce Mermaid sequence diagrams of both approaches (blocked on atproto-n83 docs restructure, then atproto-y1l)
2. Review the diagrams with the owner to decide which approach to adopt
3. Decide what to do with the current uncommitted changes in login-page.ts (revert, keep, or replace)
4. Implement the agreed approach

Key constraint: the unified single-page architecture may make a pure server-side send harder (better-auth OTP send is async and involves HTTP calls to the better-auth backend), so tradeoffs need discussion.

title: StayFocusd extension causes double OTP send
description:
The StayFocusd browser extension fetches every URL the user visits (presumably to track time spent on sites). Because the /oauth/authorize redirect is a GET request, StayFocusd triggers a remote GET to the same URL, causing a second auth_flow to be created and a second OTP email to be sent to the user.

This is benign in normal browsers without the extension, but causes confusion during development/testing. The duplicate request comes from a different IP (62.252.191.198, Virgin Media) and user-agent (Windows Chrome/144) than the real browser.

Possible mitigations:
- Make the OTP send require a POST or user interaction rather than firing on page load (so the bot's GET is harmless)
- Rate-limit OTP sends per email per time window
- Detect and ignore requests that don't have the expected browser fingerprint

title: Add Mermaid sequence diagrams for flow 1 and flow 2
description:
Create Mermaid sequence diagrams documenting the two OAuth login flows:

Flow 1: Client app has its own email form, passes login_hint to PAR, auth server skips email step and goes straight to OTP input.
Flow 2: Client app has a simple login button, auth server shows the email input form itself.

Embed directly in a docs/flows.md file (or README.md) using GitHub-native Mermaid rendering (fenced code blocks with 'mermaid' language tag). GitHub renders these natively in the web UI with no build step required.

Do NOT use separate .mmd files as these require manual PNG/SVG generation to be viewable in the GitHub UI.

title: Update recovery flow to use better-auth OTP and /_internal/account-by-email
description:
The current recovery flow (routes/recovery.ts) allows login via backup email. Update it to:
1. Use better-auth's OTP infrastructure (auth.api.sendVerificationOTP()) for verification instead of custom token service
2. Call /_internal/account-by-email for backup email→DID lookup instead of reading from account_email table
3. Integrate with the auth_flow table so request_uri is preserved through recovery

This is orthogonal to the main login flow but must use the same bridge pattern (better-auth session → /auth/complete → HMAC-signed magic-callback).

Ref: better-auth-migration-plan.md 'Open question: Recovery via backup email'
close_reason: Rewrote recovery.ts to use better-auth OTP: auth.api.sendVerificationOTP() for sending, auth.api.signInEmailOTP() for verification. After successful OTP, redirects to /auth/complete (bridge pattern) with magic_auth_flow cookie set to thread request_uri. Backup email lookup via ctx.db.getDidByBackupEmail() retained (auth-service-owned data). 9 recovery tests added, all 83 tests pass.

title: Wire email sending into better-auth sendVerificationOTP callback
description:
## Context

Part of Phase 2 of the better-auth migration plan. See `better-auth-migration-plan.md`.

## Problem

better-auth's emailOTP plugin needs a `sendVerificationOTP` callback to actually deliver OTP codes. The existing `EmailSender` class in `packages/auth-service/src/email/sender.ts` supports SMTP, SendGrid, AWS SES, and Postmark, plus custom client-branded templates. This infrastructure should be reused.

## Solution

Wire the existing `EmailSender.sendOtpCode()` into the `sendVerificationOTP` callback in `packages/auth-service/src/better-auth.ts`.

### Client branding challenge

The current template system needs a `client_id` to resolve branding (logo, colors, email template). During a better-auth emailOTP flow, the `sendVerificationOTP` callback does not have access to the OAuth client context.

Solution: read the `magic_auth_flow` cookie from the request context to recover the `flow_id`, look up the `auth_flow` row to get the `client_id`, and pass it to `emailSender.sendOtpCode()`.

If the request does not have a `magic_auth_flow` cookie (e.g., account settings login), use the default PDS email template.

## Files to modify

- `packages/auth-service/src/better-auth.ts` — wire sendVerificationOTP callback

## Acceptance criteria

- [ ] OTP emails delivered via existing EmailSender infrastructure
- [ ] Client branding applied when client_id available from auth_flow
- [ ] Default template used when no client_id context
- [ ] All four email providers (SMTP, SendGrid, SES, Postmark) still work
- [ ] Dev mode (no provider configured) still logs to console
close_reason: Wired existing EmailSender into sendVerificationOTP callback with client branding support. createBetterAuth() now accepts MagicPdsDb; callback reads magic_auth_flow cookie via ctx.getCookie(), looks up auth_flow to get client_id, passes to emailSender.sendOtpCode(). Falls back to default template when no flow context. 6 tests added. 81 tests pass.

title: Passwordless accounts missing account row causes device binding FK failure
description:
When creating a new account via magic-callback, the PDS oauth-store's createAccount() skips registerAccount() when password is undefined (condition: email && passwordScrypt). This leaves the account table empty while actor has a row. The account_device table has a FK on account.did (not actor.did), so upsertDeviceAccount() fails with SQLITE_CONSTRAINT_FOREIGNKEY.

Root cause: packages/pds-core/src/index.ts passes password: undefined to provider.accountManager.createAccount(). The PDS oauth-store.js line ~168 gates registerAccount() on both email AND passwordScrypt being truthy.

Fix applied: after createAccount() returns, manually insert a minimal account row (did, email, passwordScrypt: null) via pds.ctx.accountManager.db before calling upsertDeviceAccount(). This satisfies the FK while keeping the account passwordless.

Also discovered: account_device FK references account.did (not actor.did or device.id separately verified). WAL timing was a red herring — same DB connection is used, the row was simply never written.
notes: Additional finding: account.passwordScrypt has a NOT NULL constraint in the schema, so inserting null fails. Used sentinel value 'passwordless' instead — not a valid scrypt hash so password auth will always fail for these accounts.
close_reason: Fixed by passing a random 256-bit password to createAccount() so registerAccount() runs and the account row is created properly.

title: Eliminate account_email mirror table; use accountManager directly in pds-core
description:
## Context

Part of the better-auth migration plan. See `better-auth-migration-plan.md` (design decisions 5–6).

## Problem

pds-core currently opens the auth-service's `magic-pds.sqlite` to look up email→DID via an `account_email` mirror table, with a three-step fallback chain:
1. `magicDb.getDidByEmail(email)` — reads `account_email` in magic-pds.sqlite
2. `magicDb.getDidByBackupEmail(email)` — reads `backup_email` in magic-pds.sqlite
3. `magicDb.getDidFromPdsAccount(email)` — opens `account.sqlite` read-only as a fallback

This is redundant because the upstream PDS already stores email→DID in `account.sqlite`, and `pds.ctx.accountManager.getAccountByEmail()` is a public method that queries it directly.

## Solution

1. In pds-core's `/oauth/magic-callback` handler, replace the `magicDb.getDidByEmail()` + `magicDb.getDidFromPdsAccount()` fallback chain with a single call to `pds.ctx.accountManager.getAccountByEmail(email)`.

2. Keep the backup email lookup — but have it call `/_internal/account-by-email` or the auth-service's own `backup_email` table via HTTP (backup emails are auth-service-owned data with no PDS equivalent).

3. Remove pds-core's `MagicPdsDb` instantiation entirely — pds-core no longer opens the auth-service database.

4. Delete `getDidByEmail`, `getDidFromPdsAccount`, `setAccountEmail` from `packages/shared/src/db.ts`.

5. Drop the `account_email` table from the auth-service SQLite file.

## Files to modify

- `packages/pds-core/src/index.ts` — replace magicDb calls with accountManager; remove MagicPdsDb import and instantiation
- `packages/shared/src/db.ts` — remove getDidByEmail, getDidFromPdsAccount, setAccountEmail, and account_email table creation/migration

## Acceptance criteria

- [ ] pds-core no longer imports or instantiates MagicPdsDb
- [ ] pds-core no longer opens magic-pds.sqlite
- [ ] Magic callback uses pds.ctx.accountManager.getAccountByEmail() for email→DID lookup
- [ ] account_email table dropped from auth-service SQLite schema
- [ ] getDidByEmail, getDidFromPdsAccount, setAccountEmail removed from shared/db.ts
- [ ] New account creation still writes to account.sqlite via createAccount (unchanged)
- [ ] Login flow works end-to-end
close_reason: Removed account_email mirror table from shared/db.ts (v5 migration drops it), removed getDidByEmail/getDidFromPdsAccount/setAccountEmail/getEmailByDid methods. Updated pds-core to use pds.ctx.accountManager.getAccountByEmail() directly, removed MagicPdsDb instantiation. Updated auth-service verify-code and account-login to query /_internal/account-by-email. All 63 tests pass.

title: Install better-auth and mount alongside existing code
description:
## Context

This is Phase 1 of the better-auth migration plan. See `better-auth-migration-plan.md` for the full plan.

## Goal

Install better-auth as a dependency, configure it with emailOTP plugin, and mount it on the auth-service Express app alongside the existing routes. No existing behavior changes — this is a foundation-only step.

## Implementation

### 1.1 Install dependencies

```bash
pnpm add better-auth better-sqlite3
# better-sqlite3 is already a dependency — verify version compatibility
```

### 1.2 Create better-auth configuration

Create `packages/auth-service/src/better-auth.ts` with:
- `betterAuth()` instance configured with:
  - `database`: points to `process.env.DB_LOCATION ?? "./data/magic-pds.sqlite"` (shared auth-service SQLite)
  - `baseURL`: `https://${process.env.AUTH_HOSTNAME}`
  - `basePath`: `/api/auth` (namespaced to avoid route conflicts)
  - `emailOTP` plugin with `otpLength: 8`, `expiresIn: 600`, `allowedAttempts: 5`, `storeOTP: "hashed"`, and `sendVerificationOTP` callback wired to existing `EmailSender`
  - `socialProviders` built dynamically from env vars — `buildSocialProviders()` checks for `GOOGLE_CLIENT_ID`+`GOOGLE_CLIENT_SECRET`, `GITHUB_CLIENT_ID`+`GITHUB_CLIENT_SECRET`, etc. Only providers with both vars set are included.
  - `session.expiresIn` from `SESSION_EXPIRES_IN` env var (default 7 days)
  - `session.updateAge` from `SESSION_UPDATE_AGE` env var (default 1 day)
- Export `socialProviders` object so login page can conditionally render buttons

### 1.3 Run better-auth migrations

```bash
pnpm dlx @better-auth/cli migrate
```

Creates `user`, `session`, `account`, `verification` tables in the auth-service SQLite file alongside existing custom tables.

### 1.4 Mount on Express

In `packages/auth-service/src/index.ts`, mount before `express.json()`:

```typescript
import { toNodeHandler } from "better-auth/node";
import { auth } from "./better-auth";
app.all("/api/auth/*", toNodeHandler(auth));
```

Existing routes continue to work unchanged.

## Files to create

- `packages/auth-service/src/better-auth.ts`

## Files to modify

- `packages/auth-service/src/index.ts` — mount better-auth handler
- `packages/auth-service/package.json` — add better-auth dependency
- `.env.example` — add SESSION_EXPIRES_IN, SESSION_UPDATE_AGE, GOOGLE_CLIENT_ID, GOOGLE_CLIENT_SECRET, GITHUB_CLIENT_ID, GITHUB_CLIENT_SECRET

## Acceptance criteria

- [ ] better-auth tables created in auth-service SQLite without breaking existing tables
- [ ] `/api/auth/*` endpoints respond (better-auth health check)
- [ ] Existing OTP login flow still works unchanged
- [ ] No behavior change for users
close_reason: Installed better-auth 1.4.18 and better-sqlite3 as auth-service dependencies. Created packages/auth-service/src/better-auth.ts with betterAuth() configured with emailOTP plugin (otpLength:8, expiresIn:600, allowedAttempts:5, storeOTP:hashed) wired to existing EmailSender, dynamic social providers from env vars, and session lifetime from env. Mounted at /api/auth/* in index.ts before express.json(). Also converted auth-service to type:module (ESM) to support better-auth which is ESM-only. Fixed SMTPTransport type import in email/sender.ts. Added MAGIC_INTERNAL_SECRET, SESSION_EXPIRES_IN, SESSION_UPDATE_AGE, GOOGLE_CLIENT_ID/SECRET, GITHUB_CLIENT_ID/SECRET to .env.example. All 65 tests pass.

title: Enable social providers (Google, GitHub) via env-var config
description:
Phase 4 of the migration plan. Since buildSocialProviders() already auto-detects from env vars and the login page conditionally renders buttons:

1. Document the required env vars (GOOGLE_CLIENT_ID/SECRET, GITHUB_CLIENT_ID/SECRET) in .env.example
2. Test the full flow: social login → better-auth session → /auth/complete bridge → HMAC-signed magic-callback
3. Verify account linking: same email from social provider links to existing better-auth user
4. Handle email mismatch risk: display warning if social provider email differs from known PDS account

No changes to pds-core or the bridge route needed — the bridge always reads email from the better-auth session regardless of how the user authenticated.

Ref: better-auth-migration-plan.md Phase 4
close_reason: Documented social provider env vars in .env.example with flow description, account linking behavior, email mismatch warning, and links to OAuth credential pages. Social provider buttons already rendered in login-page.ts (atproto-sbw) and auto-detection already in better-auth.ts (atproto-bvg). Added 11 social provider tests. 94 tests total pass.

title: Migrate account settings portal to better-auth sessions
description:
## Context

Phase 3 of the better-auth migration plan. See `better-auth-migration-plan.md` Phase 3.

## Problem

The `/account/*` routes on the auth-service currently use a custom `account_session` table and `magic_account_session` cookie for session management. This should use better-auth's built-in session system instead.

## Solution

1. Replace `requireAuth(ctx)` calls with a wrapper that calls `auth.api.getSession({ headers })` to validate the better-auth session.

2. The "Account Settings Login" flow becomes: render login page → user authenticates via better-auth → session established → redirect to auth-service `/account`.

3. Session revocation routes delegate to better-auth:
   - `POST /account/session/revoke` → `auth.api.revokeSession()`
   - `POST /account/sessions/revoke-all` → `auth.api.revokeSessions()`

4. These routes stay custom (they call PDS admin APIs):
   - `POST /account/handle` — calls `com.atproto.admin.updateAccountHandle`
   - `POST /account/delete` — calls `com.atproto.admin.deleteAccount`
   - `POST /account/backup-email/*` — custom backup_email table + verification

5. Update `GET /metrics` to query better-auth's tables (user count, session count) alongside existing custom tables.

### Delete on completion

- `packages/auth-service/src/middleware/account-auth.ts`
- `packages/auth-service/src/routes/account-login.ts`
- `packages/auth-service/src/middleware/session.ts`
- Drop `account_session` table from auth-service SQLite

## Files to modify

- `packages/auth-service/src/routes/account-settings.ts` — use better-auth session
- `packages/auth-service/src/index.ts` — remove old account-auth middleware

## Files to delete

- `packages/auth-service/src/middleware/account-auth.ts`
- `packages/auth-service/src/routes/account-login.ts`
- `packages/auth-service/src/middleware/session.ts`

## Acceptance criteria

- [ ] Account settings pages use better-auth session
- [ ] Old account_session table dropped
- [ ] Session revocation works via better-auth
- [ ] Handle change, account deletion, backup email management still work
- [ ] Metrics endpoint queries better-auth tables
close_reason: Migrated /account/* routes to better-auth session management. Replaced custom account_session table + magic_account_session cookie with better-auth APIs. account-login now uses email OTP via better-auth. account-settings uses auth.api.getSession/listSessions/revokeSession/signOut. v7 migration drops account_session table. Deleted account-auth.ts and session.ts middleware. All 63 tests pass.

title: Build auth_flow table and AT Protocol bridge route
description:
## Context

Phase 2 core of the better-auth migration plan. See `better-auth-migration-plan.md` Phase 2.

## Problem

The AT Protocol OAuth flow starts with a PAR `request_uri` that must survive the authentication process and arrive at pds-core's `/oauth/magic-callback`. Currently this is threaded through HTML hidden form fields and stored in the `magic_link_token` DB row. With better-auth, the OTP/social-login flow is opaque — we cannot embed `request_uri` in better-auth's internal state.

## Solution

### auth_flow table

Add a new `auth_flow` table to the auth-service SQLite:

```sql
CREATE TABLE auth_flow (
  flow_id TEXT PRIMARY KEY,
  request_uri TEXT NOT NULL,
  client_id TEXT,
  email TEXT,
  created_at INTEGER NOT NULL,
  expires_at INTEGER NOT NULL
);
```

Cleanup: delete expired rows on the same 5-minute interval as existing token cleanup.

### Bridge route: auth-service `GET /auth/complete`

This is the route better-auth redirects to after successful authentication. It is the `callbackURL` passed to better-auth's sign-in methods.

Steps:
1. Read `magic_auth_flow` cookie → get flow_id
2. Look up auth_flow row → get request_uri, client_id
3. Get better-auth session via `auth.api.getSession({ headers })`
4. Extract verified email from session
5. Check consent needed (reuse existing client_logins logic)
6. If consent needed → redirect to auth-service `/auth/consent?flow_id=...`
7. Otherwise → build HMAC-signed redirect URL:
   - Compute HMAC-SHA256(request_uri || email || approved || new_account || ts, MAGIC_CALLBACK_SECRET)
   - Redirect to pds-core `/oauth/magic-callback?...&ts=...&sig=...`
8. Delete auth_flow row + clear cookie

## Files to create

- `packages/auth-service/src/routes/complete.ts` — the bridge route

## Files to modify

- `packages/shared/src/db.ts` — add auth_flow table creation/migration + CRUD methods
- `packages/auth-service/src/index.ts` — mount the /auth/complete route

## Acceptance criteria

- [ ] auth_flow table created in auth-service SQLite
- [ ] Expired auth_flow rows cleaned up periodically
- [ ] Bridge route reads better-auth session and extracts verified email
- [ ] Bridge route produces HMAC-signed redirect to pds-core /oauth/magic-callback
- [ ] Consent flow still works (redirect to /auth/consent when needed)
- [ ] Cookie set/cleared correctly
close_reason: Added auth_flow table (v6 migration) to shared/db.ts with createAuthFlow/getAuthFlow/deleteAuthFlow/cleanupExpiredAuthFlows CRUD methods. Created packages/auth-service/src/routes/complete.ts bridge route that reads magic_auth_flow cookie, validates auth_flow record, gets better-auth session via fromNodeHeaders, determines isNewAccount via PDS internal endpoint, handles consent redirect, and issues HMAC-signed redirect to pds-core /oauth/magic-callback. Mounted in index.ts and wired cleanup in context.ts. 67 tests pass.

title: Update consent screen to use auth_flow table
description:
## Context

Phase 2 of the better-auth migration plan. See `better-auth-migration-plan.md` Phase 2.4.

## Problem

The current consent screen (`routes/consent.ts`) reads `request_uri` directly from query parameters. With the new auth_flow-based architecture, the request_uri is stored in the `auth_flow` table, keyed by flow_id.

## Solution

Update `GET/POST /auth/consent` on the auth-service to:
- Read `flow_id` from query parameter (or `magic_auth_flow` cookie) instead of `request_uri` directly
- Look up `auth_flow` row to get `request_uri` and `client_id`
- After consent is granted, build HMAC-signed redirect URL to pds-core `/oauth/magic-callback`
- Delete the old `routes/consent.ts` implementation (replace in-place)

## Files to modify

- `packages/auth-service/src/routes/consent.ts` — rewrite to use auth_flow table

## Acceptance criteria

- [ ] Consent screen reads request_uri from auth_flow table via flow_id
- [ ] After consent, redirect is HMAC-signed
- [ ] First-time consent tracking (client_logins table) still works
- [ ] Consent screen still displays client branding
close_reason: Updated consent screen to support flow_id mode: GET reads request_uri/client_id from auth_flow table via flow_id query param. POST approves by looking up auth_flow, deletes the row after use, and builds HMAC-signed redirect to pds-core /oauth/magic-callback. Legacy direct request_uri mode retained for backward compat. complete.ts updated to pass flow_id to consent instead of request_uri, deferring auth_flow cleanup. 12 tests pass.

title: Replace /_magic/check-email with protected /_internal/account-by-email
description:
## Problem

The `/_magic/check-email` endpoint on pds-core returns `{ exists: true/false, did: "..." }` for any email with no authentication. It is an email enumeration oracle. It also reads from the `account_email` mirror table in `magic-pds.sqlite`, which we are eliminating as part of the broader migration to use `account.sqlite` as the single source of truth.

**Identified in the [magic-pds security review](https://gist.github.com/s-adamantine/c88df4fc940259cfe903e9de474f07fc#critical-vulnerabilities) as MED-4.**

See also: `better-auth-migration-plan.md` Phase 0.4

## Solution

Replace `/_magic/check-email` with `/_internal/account-by-email`, which:
- Requires `x-internal-secret` header matching `MAGIC_INTERNAL_SECRET` env var
- Queries `pds.ctx.accountManager.getAccountByEmail()` directly — the upstream PDS already has this as a public method on AccountManager (in `node_modules/@atproto/pds/src/account-manager/account-manager.ts`). It queries `account.sqlite` directly — no mirror table needed.
- Returns `{ did: string } | { did: null }`

## Implementation

1. In `packages/pds-core/src/index.ts`, add the new endpoint:

```typescript
app.get("/_internal/account-by-email", async (req, res) => {
  if (req.headers["x-internal-secret"] !== process.env.MAGIC_INTERNAL_SECRET) {
    return res.status(401).json({ error: "Unauthorized" });
  }
  const email = req.query.email as string;
  if (!email) return res.status(400).json({ error: "Missing email" });
  const account = await pds.ctx.accountManager.getAccountByEmail(email);
  res.json({ did: account?.did ?? null });
});
```

2. Update auth-service to call `/_internal/account-by-email` with `x-internal-secret` header instead of calling `/_magic/check-email`.

3. Delete `/_magic/check-email` from pds-core.

4. Add `MAGIC_INTERNAL_SECRET` to `.env.example`.

## Files to modify

- `packages/pds-core/src/index.ts` — add new endpoint, delete old one
- `packages/auth-service/src/routes/` (any file calling check-email) — update to new endpoint
- `.env.example` — add MAGIC_INTERNAL_SECRET

## Acceptance criteria

- [ ] `/_internal/account-by-email` requires x-internal-secret header
- [ ] Unauthenticated calls return 401
- [ ] Valid calls return `{ did: "..." }` or `{ did: null }`
- [ ] `/_magic/check-email` is deleted
- [ ] Auth-service uses the new endpoint successfully
close_reason: Added /_internal/account-by-email endpoint to pds-core requiring x-internal-secret header, querying pds.ctx.accountManager.getAccountByEmail() directly. Deleted /_magic/check-email. Updated auth-service account-login.ts to call the new protected endpoint. Added MAGIC_INTERNAL_SECRET to .env.example.

title: Stop assigning random passwords to new accounts
description:
## Problem

Accounts are created with a random 64-byte hex password (`crypto.randomBytes(64).toString('hex')`) in two places:
- `packages/pds-core/src/index.ts:130`
- `packages/auth-service/src/lib/auto-provision.ts:20`

This password is never shown to users but is a valid credential for `com.atproto.server.createSession`. If it were ever leaked (logs, memory dump, DB access), it bypasses the entire auth service.

**Identified in the [magic-pds security review](https://gist.github.com/s-adamantine/c88df4fc940259cfe903e9de474f07fc#critical-vulnerabilities) as MED-3.**

See also: `better-auth-migration-plan.md` Phase 0.3

## Solution

Pass `password: undefined` when creating accounts. The PDS `accountManager.createAccount()` already handles this — it sets `passwordScrypt` to `undefined`, meaning:
- `createSession` rejects login (no hash to compare against)
- Password reset has nothing to reset
- Users who later want password-based login can use the stock PDS `requestPasswordReset` → `resetPassword` flow to set one — this works even when no password was previously set

## Implementation

1. In `packages/pds-core/src/index.ts:130`, change `password: randomBytes(64).toString('hex')` to `password: undefined`
2. In `packages/auth-service/src/lib/auto-provision.ts:20`, same change
3. Verify the PDS handles passwordless accounts correctly — test that `createSession` returns a proper error (not a crash) when there is no password hash

## Acceptance criteria

- [ ] New accounts are created with no password
- [ ] `createSession` returns a clear error for passwordless accounts (not a 500)
- [ ] `requestPasswordReset` + `resetPassword` can set a password on a previously passwordless account
- [ ] Existing login flow via OTP is unaffected
close_reason: Removed random password generation from both auto-provision.ts (removed password field from XRPC call entirely since lexicon accepts optional) and pds-core/src/index.ts (used undefined as unknown as string to bypass SignUpInput schema type since no runtime schema validation at direct call site). Also removed unused crypto import from both files.

title: CRITICAL: Sign magic callback with HMAC-SHA256
description:
## Problem

The `/oauth/magic-callback` endpoint on pds-core accepts security-critical authorization decisions as plain, unsigned query parameters:

```
GET /oauth/magic-callback?request_uri=urn:...&email=victim@example.com&approved=1&new_account=0
```

An attacker who initiates a legitimate OAuth flow (getting a valid `request_uri` via PAR) can directly call the magic-callback with the victim's email instead of completing OTP verification. If the PDS port is reachable (misconfigured firewall, Docker port mapping, open redirect), any account can be taken over without any authentication factor.

**This is the most severe finding from the [magic-pds security review](https://gist.github.com/s-adamantine/c88df4fc940259cfe903e9de474f07fc#critical-vulnerabilities).**

See also: `better-auth-migration-plan.md` Phase 0.1

## Solution

Add a shared HMAC-SHA256 secret between auth-service and pds-core. The auth-service computes a signature over the callback parameters and a timestamp, appending `&ts=...&sig=...` to the redirect URL. pds-core verifies the signature before issuing an authorization code.

## Implementation

1. Add `MAGIC_CALLBACK_SECRET` env var (shared by both services). Generate with `openssl rand -hex 32`.

2. In `packages/shared/src/crypto.ts`, add `signCallback()`:
   - Input: `{ request_uri, email, approved, new_account }` + secret
   - Compute `ts = Math.floor(Date.now() / 1000)`
   - Payload: `[request_uri, email, approved, new_account, ts].join("\n")`
   - Return HMAC-SHA256 hex digest + timestamp

3. In `packages/shared/src/crypto.ts`, add `verifyCallback()`:
   - Input: same params + ts + sig + secret
   - Reject if timestamp older than 5 minutes or in the future
   - Recompute HMAC and compare with `crypto.timingSafeEqual()`
   - Return boolean

4. In auth-service `routes/verify-code.ts` and `routes/consent.ts`: call `signCallback()` when building the redirect URL to `/oauth/magic-callback`. Append `&ts=...&sig=...`.

5. In pds-core `packages/pds-core/src/index.ts`, in the `/oauth/magic-callback` handler: call `verifyCallback()` before any account operations. Return 403 on failure, 400 on expiry.

6. Update `.env.example` with `MAGIC_CALLBACK_SECRET`.

## Files to modify

- `packages/shared/src/crypto.ts` — add signCallback/verifyCallback
- `packages/pds-core/src/index.ts` — add HMAC verification at top of magic-callback handler
- `packages/auth-service/src/routes/verify-code.ts` — sign redirect URL
- `packages/auth-service/src/routes/consent.ts` — sign redirect URL
- `.env.example` — add MAGIC_CALLBACK_SECRET

## Acceptance criteria

- [ ] Unsigned requests to `/oauth/magic-callback` return 403
- [ ] Requests with expired timestamps (>5 min) return 400
- [ ] Requests with valid signatures proceed normally
- [ ] Comparison uses timingSafeEqual (no timing side-channel)
- [ ] Existing OTP login flow works end-to-end with HMAC in place
close_reason: Implemented HMAC-SHA256 signing for magic-callback: added signCallback/verifyCallback to shared/crypto.ts, updated verify-code.ts and consent.ts to sign redirects, added verification in pds-core magic-callback handler (returns 403/400 on invalid/expired sig), added MAGIC_CALLBACK_SECRET to .env.example, and added 9 new tests covering all verification paths.

title: CRITICAL: Increase OTP to 8 digits and add per-email lockout
description:
## Problem

The current OTP system uses 6 digits (1,000,000 possibilities) with 5 attempts per token and 5 tokens per email per hour. This allows 25 guesses/hour. Over days or weeks this becomes non-trivial for a targeted attack against a specific account.

**Identified in the [magic-pds security review](https://gist.github.com/s-adamantine/c88df4fc940259cfe903e9de474f07fc#critical-vulnerabilities) as CRITICAL-2.**

See also: `better-auth-migration-plan.md` Phase 0.2

## Solution

1. Increase OTP from 6 to 8 digits (100,000,000 possibilities — 100x harder brute-force)
2. Add a per-email lockout after N total failed attempts across all tokens (e.g., 15 total failures in 1 hour → lock the email for 1 hour)

## Implementation

### 8-digit OTP (current codebase)

In `packages/shared/src/crypto.ts`, change `generateOtpCode()` to generate 8-digit codes instead of 6-digit codes. This is a single-line change to the `randomInt()` range.

Update all email templates in `packages/auth-service/src/email/sender.ts` to accommodate 8-digit codes (the letter-spacing and font-size in the HTML templates may need slight adjustment).

### 8-digit OTP (after better-auth migration)

Set `otpLength: 8` in the `emailOTP` plugin configuration in `packages/auth-service/src/better-auth.ts`.

### Per-email lockout

Add a new column or table tracking total failed attempts per email across all OTP tokens within a time window. When 15 failures occur within 1 hour, reject new OTP verification attempts for that email for 1 hour. This is orthogonal to the existing per-token attempt limit (5 per token).

## Files to modify

- `packages/shared/src/crypto.ts` — change OTP digit count
- `packages/auth-service/src/email/sender.ts` — update email templates for 8-digit display
- `packages/auth-service/src/magic-link/rate-limit.ts` or `packages/shared/src/db.ts` — add per-email lockout logic

## Acceptance criteria

- [ ] OTP codes are 8 digits
- [ ] Email templates display 8 digits correctly
- [ ] Per-email lockout activates after 15 total failed attempts in 1 hour
- [ ] Lockout prevents new OTP verification (not sending — user can still request codes)
- [ ] Existing login flow works with 8-digit codes
close_reason: Increased OTP from 6 to 8 digits (100M possibilities), added per-email lockout (15 failures/hour → 1-hour lock) via new otp_failed_attempts table in db.ts with migration v4, updated token.ts to check and record failures, updated email templates for 8-digit display, added lockout test.

title: Build unified login page with multiple auth methods
description:
## Context

Phase 2 of the better-auth migration plan. See `better-auth-migration-plan.md` Phase 2.4.

## Problem

The current auth-service login flow is hardcoded for email OTP only (authorize.ts → send-code.ts → verify-code.ts). It needs to become a landing page offering multiple login methods.

## Solution

Replace the existing `GET /oauth/authorize` on the auth-service with a unified login page that:

1. Receives `?request_uri=...&client_id=...&prompt=...&login_hint=...` from the pds-core AS metadata redirect
2. Creates an `auth_flow` row (flow_id, request_uri, client_id)
3. Sets `magic_auth_flow` cookie (10 min, httpOnly)
4. Resolves client metadata for branding via existing `lib/client-metadata.ts` (logo, colors, name)
5. Renders a login page with:
   - Email OTP form (calls better-auth `/api/auth/*` endpoints on auth-service)
   - Social login buttons (only for providers enabled via env vars — check exported `socialProviders` object from `better-auth.ts`)
   - "Recover with backup email" link (to existing recovery flow)

### Social provider buttons

The login page template conditionally renders buttons based on `socialProviders`:
```typescript
if ("google" in socialProviders) { /* render Google button */ }
if ("github" in socialProviders) { /* render GitHub button */ }
```

Social login redirects to better-auth `/api/auth/sign-in/{provider}`, which handles the full OAuth exchange and redirects back to `/auth/complete` (the bridge route).

### Delete on completion

After this is working, delete the old files:
- `routes/authorize.ts`, `routes/send-code.ts`, `routes/verify-code.ts`
- `magic-link/token.ts`, `magic-link/rate-limit.ts`
- `middleware/rate-limit.ts`, `middleware/csrf.ts`
- Drop `magic_link_token` table from auth-service SQLite

Also remove `tokenService` and `rateLimiter` from `context.ts`.

## Files to create

- `packages/auth-service/src/routes/login-page.ts` — unified login page

## Files to modify

- `packages/auth-service/src/index.ts` — mount new /oauth/authorize, remove old routes
- `packages/auth-service/src/context.ts` — remove tokenService, rateLimiter

## Files to delete

- `packages/auth-service/src/routes/authorize.ts`
- `packages/auth-service/src/routes/send-code.ts`
- `packages/auth-service/src/routes/verify-code.ts`
- `packages/auth-service/src/magic-link/token.ts`
- `packages/auth-service/src/magic-link/rate-limit.ts`
- `packages/auth-service/src/middleware/rate-limit.ts`
- `packages/auth-service/src/middleware/csrf.ts`

## Acceptance criteria

- [ ] Login page renders with email OTP form
- [ ] Social login buttons appear only for configured providers
- [ ] Client branding (logo, name, colors) displayed from OAuth metadata
- [ ] Email OTP flow works end-to-end through better-auth
- [ ] Social login (if configured) works end-to-end through better-auth → /auth/complete bridge
- [ ] Old OTP route files deleted
- [ ] Old middleware files deleted
- [ ] context.ts cleaned up
close_reason: Created routes/login-page.ts: unified GET /oauth/authorize that creates auth_flow row, sets magic_auth_flow cookie, renders login page with better-auth email OTP form (JavaScript fetch to /api/auth/* endpoints) and optional social provider buttons (Google/GitHub via env vars). Client branding applied. Deleted old authorize.ts, send-code.ts, verify-code.ts. Removed tokenService/rateLimiter from context.ts, deleted magic-link/ directory. 10 login-page tests added, 83 tests total pass.
